questions.text: Which of the following EEG wave patterns is typically associated with specific states of consciousness or neurological activity in humans, and what does it correctly indicate?

choices.text: Alpha waves (8-12 Hz) - Indicate deep sleep and unconsciousness.
Theta waves (4-7 Hz) - Often seen in drowsiness and can indicate potential seizures.
Beta waves (13-30 Hz) - Commonly associated with relaxed wakefulness and mental activity.
Delta waves (0.5-4 Hz) - Associated with REM sleep and alertness.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Theta waves (4-7 Hz) - Often seen in drowsiness and can indicate potential seizures.

 

Explanation:

  • EEG waves are patterns of electrical activity in the brain that are categorized by their frequency.
  • Each type of wave is associated with different states of consciousness or neurological activity:

Delta Wave

  • Seen in slow wave deep sleep or delta sleep. (Option D)
  • Also seen in infants.
  • Frequency: 0.5-3 Hz.
  • Amplitude or the micro voltage- High, ≥75 V.

Theta waves

  • The transition from wakefulness to sleep.
  • 1st wave that is encountered in sleep.
  • Also seen in children.
  • Frequency: 4-7 Hz.
  • Low-voltage waves.
  • Prominently seen in the temporal and parietal regions.

Alpha Waves

  • Seen at rest - When the person is awake but the eyes are closed. (Option A)
  • Frequency: 8-13Hz.
  • Low-voltage waves.
  • Seen in occipital and parieto-occipital areas.

Beta Wave

  • Seen in a fully awake person (eyes open). (Option C)
  • Frequency: Higher, 14-30 Hz.
  • Low-voltage waves.
  • Present in the frontal and parietal areas.

Gamma wave
  • High-frequency brain activity.
  • Frequencies between 30-100 Hz.
  • Prominent during REM sleep.
  • Contribute to the consolidation of memories and processing of information.

questions.text: Which stage of sleep is primarily associated with the deepest sleep, characterized by the lowest levels of brain activity and the greatest difficulty in awakening?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) N3 sleep

Explanation:

  • N3 sleep is associated with the lowest levels of brain activity and the most difficulty in awakening.

Sleep is divided into 2 stages:

  1. NREM sleep
  2. REM sleep

 

NREM:

NREM is divided into 3 stages

  • Stage 1: N1 stage
  • Stage 2: N2 stage
  • Stage 3 and Stage 4: Stages 3 and 4 have been combined into one stage known as the N3 stage.

 

Stage

EEG

EOG

EMG

Awake (Stage W)

Alpha waves (8-13 Hz) with eyes closed

Eye movements and blinks present

High tonic activity, voluntary movements

N1 Stage (Light Sleep) (Option A)

Loss of alpha waves, theta waves (4-7 Hz)

Slow eye movements

Tonic activity decreases

N2 Stage (Moderate Sleep) (Option B)

Sleep spindles (12-14 Hz), K complexes (sharp negative followed by positive waves)

None

Very low tonic activity

N3 Stage (Deep Sleep)

Delta waves (slow, high amplitude)

None

Low tonic activity

 

Stage 4 NREM (Option D) is sometimes differentiated but largely overlaps with Stage 3 in terms of characteristics. Predominantly delta waves (low-frequency, high-amplitude brain waves), indicate very deep sleep.

questions.text:
Examine the given EEG, EOG, and EMG recordings. Which of the following statements best describes the physiological characteristics based on these recordings?
 



{{caption_text}}

choices.text: EEG shows high amplitude, low-frequency waves; EOG shows minimal eye movement; EMG shows high muscle tone.
EEG shows low amplitude, mixed frequency waves; EOG shows rapid eye movements; EMG shows atonia (reduced muscle tone).
EEG shows slow waves; EOG shows no eye movement; EMG shows regular muscle contractions.
EEG shows spikes and waves; EOG shows slow rolling eye movements; EMG shows normal muscle tone

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) EEG shows low amplitude, mixed frequency waves; EOG shows rapid eye movements; EMG shows atonia (reduced muscle tone).

Explanation:

  • EEG in REM sleep shows low amplitude, mixed frequency waves, similar to an awake state.
  • EOG shows rapid eye movements, characteristic of this sleep stage.
  • EMG shows atonia, meaning there is a near-complete loss of muscle tone, preventing movement during vivid dreaming.

 

REM sleep:

EEG findings:

  • EEG activity is increased similar to the awake state (beta activity) along with the return of alpha activity (Option A)
  • The typical appearance of these waves which are known as Sawtooth waves or Sawtooth appearance.
  • Paradoxical sleep: Even though the person is sleeping the EEG shows activity similar to the awake state.
  • PGO (Ponto Geniculo Occipital) spikes are also seen - Large phasic potentials that originate from Pons (the cholinergic neurons) and go towards the lateral geniculate body and to the occipital spikes.

 

EOG findings: Rapid eye movements are seen (Option A)

 

EMG findings: Tonic atonia (as if the muscle is in paralysis) with phasic twitches (Option D)

 

EEG shows slow waves; EOG shows no eye movement; EMG shows regular muscle contractions (Option C): Slow waves are seen in deep NREM sleep (N3), not REM sleep, and there are no muscle contractions in REM due to atonia.

questions.text: What does a sleep stage histogram typically represent in sleep studies, and which of the following best describes its key components?

choices.text: The frequency of waking episodes throughout the night and their duration.
The distribution of sleep stages (NREM and REM) over the course of the night and the amount of time spent in each stage.
The average heart rate during each hour of sleep shows changes in cardiac activity.
The brainwave activity is measured in Hertz (Hz) across different sleep stages, illustrating neurological patterns.

questions.solution:
• A sleep stage histogram is a graphical representation that shows the distribution of different sleep stages (such as NREM and REM sleep) throughout the sleep cycle.
  • It typically displays the amount of time spent in each stage over the course of the night, providing insights into sleep architecture.
  • This helps clinicians evaluate sleep quality and diagnose sleep disorders.

 

It typically reflects:

  • The sequence and duration of various sleep stages (N1, N2, N3, and REM) throughout the night.
  • The cyclic nature of sleep shows transitions between stages over time and the relative amount of time spent in each stage.

Fig: Sleep stage histogram

The frequency of waking episodes throughout the night and their duration (Option A): The sleep stage histogram does not specifically focus on waking episodes or their durations; its primary function is to map the sleep architecture.

 

The average heart rate during each hour of sleep shows changes in cardiac activity (Option C): This option refers to cardiac activity, which is not depicted in a sleep stage histogram. Cardiac data may be part of a polysomnographic study but is represented separately.

 

The brainwave activity is measured in Hertz (Hz) across different sleep stages, illustrating neurological patterns (Option D): Brainwave activity is measured by EEG but is not typically represented in a sleep stage histogram. The hypnogram instead emphasizes sleep stages, not detailed EEG frequencies.

questions.text: A sleep study reveals that a patient experiences increased muscle tone and vivid dreaming. Based on this finding, which of the following statements best differentiates REM sleep from NREM sleep?

choices.text: REM sleep is associated with increased muscle tone, while NREM sleep features muscle atonia.
REM sleep is associated with muscle atonia, whereas NREM sleep features increased muscle tone.
REM sleep occurs only in the early hours of the night, while NREM sleep predominates throughout the night.
REM sleep is marked by delta waves, while NREM sleep is marked by alpha waves.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) REM sleep is associated with muscle atonia, whereas NREM sleep features increased muscle tone.

Explanation:

  • REM sleep is characterized by muscle atonia (nearly complete paralysis of skeletal muscles), except for the muscles responsible for eye movement and breathing.
  • This atonia helps prevent the body from acting out dreams.
  • NREM sleep, on the other hand, has increased muscle tone and does not involve vivid dreaming as seen in REM sleep.

REM

NREM
  • Paradoxical sleep- asleep but the EEG is showing the activity of the active day.
  • Brain activity and physiological activity area increased or same as in the awake state except for the muscle tone (the muscles are in the state of paralysis).
  • Known as desynchronized sleep: Lots of variables in REM
  • Body movements are absent.
  • Penile erection is present.
  • Dreams are remembered.

Disorders:

  1. Narcolepsy
  2. Nightmares
  3. REM sleep behavior disorder
  4. Sleep apnea
  • Known as orthodox or conventional sleep
  • Brain activity & physiological activity are lower than in the awake state.
  • Known as synchronized- minimal variations are there in parameters such as pulse rate, respiratory rate, and BP.
  • Pulsatile release of Gonadotropins and Growth hormones.
  • Body movements are present.
  • Penile erection is absent.
  • Dreams are not remembered.

Disorders:

  1. Somnambulism (sleepwalking)
  2. Night terror
  3. Bruxism
  4. Nocturnal enuresis
  5. Somniloquy (sleep talking)

 

Polysomnography:

  • It is the continuous, attended, comprehensive recording of the physiologic changes that occur during sleep.
  • A polysomnogram is typically recorded at night and lasts between 6 and 8 hours.
  • The following are assessed during sleep:
    • Brain wave activity (EEG)
    • Eye movements (EOG)
    • Submentalis electromyography activity (EMG)
    • Nasal–oral airflow
    • Nasal pressure
    • Respiratory effort
    • Oxyhemoglobin saturation
    • Heart rhythm
    • Leg movements
    • Body position
    • Snoring sounds

REM sleep is associated with increased muscle tone, while NREM sleep features muscle atonia (Option A):

  • This option incorrectly switches the characteristics of muscle tone in REM and NREM sleep.
  • In REM sleep, there is muscle atonia (loss of muscle tone), whereas in NREM sleep, muscle tone is generally increased.

 

REM sleep occurs only in the early hours of the night, while NREM sleep predominates throughout the night (Option C):

  • REM sleep does not occur only in the early hours; it increases in duration as the night goes on, particularly in the latter part of sleep.
  • NREM sleep does dominate the early part of the night but is interspersed with REM periods throughout the sleep cycles

 

REM sleep is marked by delta waves, while NREM sleep is marked by alpha waves (Option D):

  • NREM sleep (Non-Rapid Eye Movement sleep) consists of several stages, including light sleep (Stage 1), moderate sleep (Stage 2), and deep sleep (Stage 3), which are characterized by slower brain waves, including delta waves in deep sleep.
  • Muscle tone is generally more preserved during NREM sleep compared to REM.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with difficulty falling asleep and frequent awakenings for the past six months. He reports feeling fatigued during the day but denies any history of substance use, psychiatric illness, or significant stressors. His physical examination and laboratory tests are unremarkable. He has tried over-the-counter sleep aids with little effect. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I)

Explanation:

  • Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I) is the first-line treatment for chronic insomnia.
  • It addresses maladaptive thoughts and behaviors related to sleep and has long-term benefits with minimal side effects.
  • Sleep restriction therapy and stimulus control are components of CBT-I, where patients gradually reduce their time in bed to increase sleep efficiency.

 

Insomnia is characterized by dissatisfaction with the amount or quality of sleep, leading to significant distress or difficulties in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

 

Types of Insomnia:

As per ICSD-3 (International Classification of Sleep Disorder)

  • Acute or Short-term insomnia disorder: <3 months
  • Chronic insomnia disorder: ≥3 months

 

Previous guidelines classify insomnia into:

  • Primary - without a specific cause
    • Psychophysiologic
    • Idiopathic
    • Paradoxical
  • Secondary- due to some other disorder

 

DSM-5 classifies as:

  • Episodic (lasting 1–3 mo)
  • Persistent (lasting ≥3 mo)
  • Recurrent (two or more episodes occurring within 1 y)

 

Insomnia in general may present as:

  • Difficulty falling asleep - Initial Insomnia
  • Difficulty maintaining sleep - Middle Insomnia
  • Early morning awakenings - Late Insomnia

 

Management of Insomnia:

1. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I)

CBT-I is the first-line treatment for chronic insomnia, conducted over a 6- to 8-week period. It is highly effective and focuses on changing behaviors and thoughts that affect sleep. It involves several components:

  • Cognitive Therapy
  • Relaxation or Meditation Therapy
  • Sleep Education
  • Sleep Restriction Therapy
  • Stimulus Control Therapy

 

2. Medications for Insomnia

  • Benzodiazepine Receptor Agonists - zolpidem, zaleplon, and eszopiclone
  • Melatonin Receptor Agonists - Ramelteon
  • Orexin Receptor Antagonists - Suvorexant
  • Benzodiazepines

 

Melatonin supplements (Option B):

  • Melatonin is often used for circadian rhythm sleep disorders, such as delayed sleep phase syndrome, and may have some benefit in insomnia.
  • However, it is not considered a first-line treatment for chronic insomnia.

 

Benzodiazepines (Option C):

  • While effective in inducing sleep, benzodiazepines are not first-line treatments for chronic insomnia due to their potential for tolerance, dependence, and withdrawal.
  • They may be considered for short-term use in acute insomnia but should be avoided for long-term management.

 

Antihistamines (Option D):

  • While easily available, antihistamines are not effective long-term solutions for insomnia and can cause side effects like drowsiness and confusion, especially in older adults.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with complaints of difficulty falling asleep and frequent nocturnal awakenings. She describes an uncomfortable sensation in her legs, often accompanied by an irresistible urge to move them, particularly in the evening and at night. These symptoms subside temporarily after moving her legs but recur shortly after. She denies any history of substance use, and her medical history is unremarkable. What is the most likely cause of her insomnia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Restless Leg Syndrome

Explanation:

Restless Leg Syndrome (RLS) also known as Willis-Ekbom Disease is characterized by an uncomfortable sensation in the legs, especially in the evening or at night, which leads to an irresistible urge to move them.

  • The movement temporarily relieves the discomfort, but the symptoms soon return, causing difficulty falling asleep or maintaining sleep.
  • This leads to insomnia, which is a common complaint in patients with RLS.

 

Features of RLS include:

  • Sensations that begin after rest
  • Relief of discomfort with movement
  • Worsening of symptoms at night with a distinct symptom-free period in the early morning

 

Treatment of Restless Legs Syndrome (RLS)

  • No definite cure, but symptoms can be managed.
  • Movement of affected limbs may provide temporary relief.
  • Treat underlying conditions like peripheral neuropathy, diabetes, or iron deficiency anemia to control symptoms.

Medications:

  • Iron supplements: For RLS linked to iron deficiency.
  • Anti-seizure drugs (first-line treatment):
    • FDA-approved: Gabapentin enacarbil, others like pregabalin.
  • Dopaminergic agents:
    • FDA-approved: Ropinirole, pramipexole, rotigotine.
    • Levodopa + carbidopa are used intermittently.
  • Opioids: For severe cases unresponsive to other drugs (e.g., methadone, oxycodone).
  • Benzodiazepines: For better sleep (clonazepam, lorazepam).

 

Lifestyle Modifications:

  • Avoid alcohol, nicotine, and caffeine.
  • Maintain a regular sleep pattern.
  • Engage in moderate exercise.
  • Use leg massage, warm baths, heating pads, or foot wraps for relief.

 

Periodic Limb Movement Disorder (PLMD) (Option A) involves repetitive, involuntary jerking or movements of the limbs during sleep, which may cause brief arousals but does not necessarily involve the urge to move the legs as seen in RLS. While both PLMD and RLS can cause sleep disturbances, RLS symptoms occur primarily before sleep onset, while PLMD typically occurs during sleep.

 

Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA) (Option B) is characterized by repetitive episodes of partial or complete obstruction of the airway during sleep, leading to fragmented sleep and daytime fatigue. While OSA can cause insomnia, the hallmark of OSA is loud snoring and witnessed apneas, neither of which is mentioned in this case.

 

Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD) (Option D) can cause insomnia due to excessive worry and hyperarousal, but the physical symptoms of RLS, such as leg discomfort and the urge to move, are not characteristic of anxiety disorders. Anxiety-related insomnia typically involves difficulty falling asleep due to racing thoughts rather than discomfort in the legs.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with excessive daytime sleepiness for the past six months. He describes episodes where he suddenly loses muscle tone and falls to the ground after laughing. These episodes increase in situations when he becomes very emotional. He also reports experiencing vivid, dream-like hallucinations upon waking and occasional paralysis on waking from sleep. Based on the clinical picture, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Narcolepsy Type 1

Explanation:

Narcolepsy Type 1 is a REM disorder characterized by excessive daytime sleepiness, reduced REM latency, cataplexy (sudden loss of muscle tone triggered by emotions like laughter), hypnagogic or hypnopompic hallucinations (vivid hallucinations occurring while falling asleep or waking up), and sleep paralysis (temporary inability to move upon awakening).

  • These are classic symptoms described in this scenario.

 

Types of Narcolepsy:

As per ICSD 3:

Type 1:

  1. Excessive sleepiness
  2. Cataplexy with or without hypocretin 1 deficiency
  3. Mean sleep latency of ≤8 min and two sleep-onset rapid eye movement periods (SOREMP) within 15 min of sleep onset.

Type 2:

  • Cataplexy and/or hypocretin deficiency not present
  • Other features of type 1 are present.

According to DSM 5:

  • Narcolepsy without cataplexy but with hypocretin deficiency
  • Narcolepsy with cataplexy but without hypocretin deficiency
  • Autosomal dominant cerebellar ataxia, deafness, and narcolepsy (due to genetic mutation and characterized by late onset in the 30s and 40s)
  • Autosomal dominant narcolepsy, obesity, and type 2 diabetes (associated with mutation in myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein gene)
  • Narcolepsy secondary to another medical condition

Severity of Narcolepsy as per DSM 5:

  • Mild: <1/week, 1–2 naps daily mildly, or intermittently disturbed sleep.
  • Moderate: cataplexy 1/day. Disturbed sleep, need for multiple naps.
  • Severe: near constant. Multiple attacks/day. Disturbed sleep. Resistant to medications.

 

Treatment of Narcolepsy:

  1. Behavior Modification:
    • Scheduled naps (15-20 minutes) throughout the day.
    • Maintain a proper nighttime sleep schedule.
    • Emotional support, mental health counselling, and education on avoiding alcohol/illicit drugs.
    • Exercise is also recommended.
  2. Pharmacological Treatment:
    • For Excessive Daytime Sleepiness:
      • First-line: Modafinil (twice daily) or Armodafinil (once daily).
      • Second-line: Amphetamines.
    • For Cataplexy:
      • First-line: Sodium Oxybate (taken in bed, second dose after 2.5-4 hours). Sodium oxybate is restricted and should not be mixed with CNS depressants or alcohol.
      • Alternatives: Tricyclic antidepressants (protriptyline, clomipramine), SNRIs/SSRIs (venlafaxine, fluoxetine).


 

Obstructive Sleep Apnea (Option B) presents with daytime sleepiness due to disrupted nighttime sleep but does not feature cataplexy, hypnagogic hallucinations, or sleep paralysis.

  • It is caused by intermittent airway obstruction during sleep.

 

Idiopathic Hypersomnia (Option C) also leads to excessive daytime sleepiness but lacks the hallmark features of cataplexy, hypnagogic hallucinations, and sleep paralysis seen in narcolepsy.

 

Narcolepsy Type 2 (Option D) has similar symptoms to Type 1 but lacks cataplexy.

  • The presence of cataplexy in this patient favors Narcolepsy Type 1.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is diagnosed with narcolepsy after presenting with excessive daytime sleepiness and episodes of cataplexy triggered by laughter. She also experiences sleep paralysis and hypnagogic hallucinations. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for her excessive daytime sleepiness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Modafinil

Explanation:

Modafinil is a first-line treatment for excessive daytime sleepiness in narcolepsy.

  • It promotes wakefulness with a lower potential for abuse compared to traditional stimulants like amphetamines.
  • It is well-tolerated and improves the patient's quality of life by reducing daytime sleepiness.
  • The management of narcolepsy involves a combination of behavioral modifications and pharmacological interventions to address both excessive daytime sleepiness and cataplexy.

1. Behavioral Modification:

  • Patients are encouraged to take 15 to 20-minute naps at strategic times during the day and to maintain good sleep hygiene at night. These naps help to alleviate excessive daytime sleepiness.
  • Exercise is also recommended.

 

2. Pharmacological Treatment:

  • For Excessive Daytime Sleepiness (EDS):
    • The first-line treatment is Modafinil (administered twice daily) or Armodafinil (once daily), both of which promote wakefulness.
    • In cases where these are ineffective, amphetamines may be used as second-line treatment.
  • For Cataplexy:
    • The first-line treatment for cataplexy is Sodium Oxybate, which induces sleep quickly and is administered in two doses—once while in bed and again 2.5 to 4 hours later.
    • Tricyclic antidepressants (e.g., protriptyline, clomipramine) and SSRIs/SNRIs (e.g., venlafaxine, fluoxetine) are also used effectively for cataplexy management.

 

Clonazepam (Option B) is primarily used to treat parasomnias such as REM sleep behavior disorder, but it is not effective for managing daytime sleepiness or cataplexy in narcolepsy.

 

Zolpidem (Option C) is a sedative-hypnotic used for the short-term management of insomnia. It would not address excessive daytime sleepiness or cataplexy in narcolepsy patients.

 

Fluoxetine (Option D) is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) that can be used to treat cataplexy by reducing the frequency of episodes, but it is not the initial treatment for excessive daytime sleepiness. It may be considered an adjunct therapy for cataplexy management.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male presents with recurrent episodes of excessive sleep lasting for several days to weeks. His parents report that during these episodes, he sleeps for 18-20 hours a day, is difficult to wake and when awake, he exhibits irritability, hyperphagia, and hypersexual behavior. Between episodes, he returns to his normal baseline functioning without any neurological deficits. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Major Depressive Disorder with Atypical Features

questions.solution:
Kleine-Levin Syndrome (KLS) is a rare, recurrent disorder characterized by episodes of hypersomnia, hyperphagia, hypersexuality, and behavioral disturbances such as irritability and confusion.

  • The episodes typically last days to weeks and are separated by periods of normal behavior and cognitive function.
  • The hallmark of the syndrome is the cyclical pattern of symptoms with complete recovery between episodes.

 

Kleine-Levin Syndrome (KLS):

  • Periods of excessive sleep (18-20 hours/day) lasting for days to weeks, followed by normal functioning. (Recurrent Hypersomnia)
  • Typically affects adolescent males, though females and older adults can also be affected. Most cases begin between ages 10 and 21.
  • Symptoms During Episodes:
    • Extreme and prolonged sleep
    • Hyperphagia (excessive eating), hypersexuality, irritability, social withdrawal, and disinhibition (e.g., aggression).
  • Episodes may occur 1 to 10 times per year.
  • Some patients exhibit only hypersomnia without other behavioral symptoms.
  • The condition is usually sporadic, though familial cases have been reported

 

Narcolepsy (Option A) is characterized by excessive daytime sleepiness, sleep attacks, and often cataplexy, hypnagogic hallucinations, and sleep paralysis.

  • It does not involve prolonged episodes of hypersomnia, hyperphagia, or hypersexuality.
  • Narcolepsy is more continuous, rather than episodic like Kleine-Levin Syndrome.

 

Major Depressive Disorder with Atypical Features (Option C) may involve hypersomnia and hyperphagia, but it lacks the episodic nature and additional symptoms of hypersexuality and irritability seen in Kleine-Levin Syndrome.

  • Patients with atypical depression typically experience mood reactivity, feelings of heaviness in limbs, and sensitivity to rejection, which are absent in KLS.

 

Bipolar Disorder - Manic Episode (Option D) may present with hypersexuality and irritability, but it is typically associated with a reduced need for sleep rather than hypersomnia.

  • Additionally, mania includes symptoms like grandiosity, pressured speech, and increased goal-directed activity, which are not features of Kleine-Levin Syndrome.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to a sleep clinic with episodes of walking around her house at night while appearing to be asleep. She performs complex tasks, sometimes injuring herself, and has no recollection of these activities in the morning. Her doctor notes she experiences heightened stress and occasional sleep deprivation. Which of the following is NOT classified as an NREM-related parasomnia?
questions.solution:
Sleepwalking, Sleep Terrors, and Confusional Arousals are all NREM-related parasomnias, while nightmares occur during REM sleep

 

NREM related Parasomnias

Sleepwalking (Somnambulism)
  • Involves walking or engaging in complex behaviors while in a state of unconsciousness, which may lead to injuries or dangerous situations.
  • Typically occurs during slow-wave sleep, starting in the first or second slow-wave episodes.
  • Can be triggered by sleep deprivation and disruption of slow-wave sleep..
  • Difficult to awaken; they often appear confused when roused.
  • More common in children, with a peak prevalence between ages 4 and 8, and usually resolves by adolescence.
  • Can occur as a primary disorder or secondary to another sleep issue, like sleep apnea.

Night Terrors
  • Night terrors involve sudden arousal with intense fear, often starting with a scream.
  • Accompanied by signs of severe anxiety and confusion; individuals are unresponsive to stimuli.
  • Typically occurs during slow-wave sleep and may be triggered by fever or CNS depressant withdrawal.
  • Amnesia for the episode is common.
  • Unlike nightmares, sleep terrors may lack detailed imagery.

Confusional Arousals
  • Defined as a milder form of NREM sleep parasomnia, often seen in children.
  • Involves partial awakening, confusion, and then returning to sleep.
  • Believed to be on a continuum with sleepwalking and sleep terrors.

Sleep-Related Eating Disorder

  
  • Classified under NREM sleep arousal disorders, specifically as “sleepwalking with sleep-related eating.”
  • Involves episodes of eating during sleep, often with no awareness of the behavior.
  • Can lead to weight gain and health issues, including injuries while preparing food.

Sleep Talking (Somniloquy)
  • Speaking during sleep without awareness is often incoherent or nonsensical.
  • Occurs during stages N1 and N2, but can also happen in REM.
  • Can vary from rare occurrences to frequent episodes, lasting for a few seconds or minutes.
  • Can occur independently or alongside other parasomnias like sleepwalking or night terrors.
  • Stress, sleep deprivation, alcohol, or fever may trigger episodes.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the clinic by his partner, who reports that he frequently acts out his dreams during sleep. She describes him kicking, punching, and even shouting while asleep, often appearing very distressed. He has no recollection of these events upon waking and has no history of sleepwalking. His partner expresses concern about the risk of injury to both of them during these episodes. On polysomnography, REM sleep without atonia was seen. Which condition is this patient most likely experiencing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) REM Sleep Behavior Disorder

Explanation:

REM Sleep Behavior Disorder (RBD) is characterized by acting out dreams due to the absence of muscle paralysis during REM sleep, matching the patient’s symptoms of kicking, punching, and shouting.

REM related Parasomnias

Nightmare Disorder

(Option A ruled out)
  • Nightmares are frightening dreams that wake the person sleeping.
  • They are often remembered.
  • Common in children (ages 3-6) but rare in adults.
  • Can lead to insomnia due to fear of sleeping.
  • Associated with PTSD and traumatic events.
  • Certain medications and substance abuse can trigger nightmares.
  • Treatment:
    • Behavioral techniques like desensitization, exposure therapy, image rehearsal therapy, and cognitive therapy can be effective.
    • Medications such as prazosin, nitrazepam, and triazolam may also help, especially for PTSD-related nightmares.

REM Sleep Behavior Disorder (RBD)
  • RBD involves acting out dreams due to lack of sleep paralysis.
  • Individuals may punch or kick while dreaming.
  • They are unaware of their surroundings during episodes.
  • Actions relate directly to dream content.
  • There is a risk of injury to themselves or others.
  • Various drugs and conditions can worsen RBD.
  • On polysomnography, REM sleep without atonia may be seen.
  • May be associated with DLB, Parkinson's disease.

Recurrent Isolated Sleep Paralysis

(Option C ruled out)
  • Sleep paralysis is the inability to move during sleep onset or awakening.
  • It can be distressing and may include hallucinations.
  • It can occur independently of narcolepsy.
  • Paralysis can last from one to several minutes.
  • Risk factors include irregular sleep, stress, and sleep deprivation.
  • Treatment:
    • Improved sleep hygiene and ensuring sufficient sleep are primary treatments.
    • Rapid eye movements or being touched may help terminate episodes.

 

Sleep Terrors (Option D): These typically occur during non-REM sleep, involve screaming or intense fear, and are usually not remembered by the individual upon waking.
